dataset.title: Crossing Treeline: Bacterioplankton community composition in alpine and subalpine lakes of the Rocky Mountain southern ecoregion and associated physical and chemical characteristics

associatedParty.role: Field Crew, Lab Analysis, Conceptual Content

abstract.para: This dataset includes lake water samples collected in the summer of 2016 from 16 different mountain lakes in the Rocky mountains in both Rocky Mountain National Park and the Snowy Range of southern Wyoming. Each lake was sampled twice: once in the early summer when hydrologic connections with the surrounding terrestrial environment were high and again in the late summer when hydrologic connections were low. The main goal of the study was to compare communities of bacterioplankton in alpine and subalpine lakes to determine if communities differed across treeline as soil microbes in the surrounding terrestrial environment were. To do so, we collected water samples from the deepest point of each lake, mixed it with a surface water sample and characterized bacterioplankton communities with 16S sequencing technology. Additionally, we wanted to identify abiotic factors that may correlate with community dissimilarity and characterized a suite of chemical attributes for each lake. Lake characteristics reported included surface temperature, soluble reactive phosphorous (SRP), ammonia (NH3+), pH, total dissolved nitrogen (TDN), total dissolved phosphorus (TDP), and total dissolved organic carbon (DOC), and chlorophyll a (chl-a).

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Rocky Mountain National Park and Snowy Range, Colorado and Wyoming, USA

description.para: Sample collection During the summer of 2016, we sampled 16 lakes in drainages that spanned treeline in the Southern Rocky Mountain ecoregion twice during the growing season: once at the beginning of summer and again near the end. The first visit was made in July, as early as possible after ice-off to safely access the upper most lake in each drainage and the second visit was made approximately five weeks later. Three of the four drainages were located in Rocky Mountain National Park (RMNP), Colorado; and the fourth was located in the Snowy Range of southern Wyoming (Figure 1). The Snowy Range drainage was chosen for comparison with RMNP lakes to determine if the alpine treeline pattern held in different geographic locations. Each drainage contained two lakes above (alpine) and two below (subalpine) treeline. Shrubs and tundra vegetation were present in the terrestrial environment surrounding the alpine lakes in all four drainages. The lakes range in elevation from approximately 2,800 m to 3,600 m. Vegetation at treeline was dominated by Engelmann spruce (Picea engelmannii) and lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta).

We accessed backcountry lakes by foot, and to avoid potential contamination of pathogens or aquatic invasive species, we sampled upper lakes first, and worked down the drainage to the lower elevation lakes. At the deepest point of each lake (accessed with an inflatable Alpaca raft), we recorded water temperature and the depth. We collected two water samples at the deepest point of the lake: one from the surface of the lake (grab sample) and one from approximately 1 m above the bottom of the lake with an acrylic Van Dorn bottle. Samples were collected in acid washed and triple DI rinsed 500 ml HDPE bottles. We mixed even volumes of the surface and the bottom samples to create one representative sample for each lake. All lakes within a drainage were sampled between the hours of 0800 and 1300 and within 36 hours of one another to minimize potential temporal effects.

Sample processing Within 12 hours of collection, we hand-filtered between 500 ml and 1,000 ml lake water through 0.7 Âµm pore size glass fiber filters (GF/F, pre-combusted at 475o C for 4 hours) and 500 ml though 0.2 Âµm pore size sterile filters in the field. The filtrate (0.7 Âµm pore size filter) was transferred to high-density polyethylene (HDPE) plastic bottles and kept for water chemistry characterization. We transferred the 0.7 Âµm GF/F filters (chlorophyll-a samples) and 0.2 Âµm filters (microbial samples) to sterile plastic vials.

Chemical analyses We characterized the chemical properties of the water samples at the University of Colorado (Boulder, CO). Ammonia (NH3+) and soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) were analyzed immediately upon return to the laboratory. Before freezing, we warmed 50 ml of the sample to room temperature and recorded pH. The remaining filtrate was frozen (-20Â°C) until analysis within three months for total dissolved nitrogen (TDN), total dissolved phosphorus (TDP), and total dissolved organic carbon (DOC). We analyzed TDP colorimetrically (Grasshoff et al.Â 2009), TDN with an ion chromatograph, and DOC using a Shimadzu model 7100 carbon analyzer. We extracted chlorophyll a (chl-a) from the 0.7 Âµm GF/F filters using the 90% hot ethanol method (Nusch 1980), then covered samples in foil and kept refrigerated (4Â°C) until analysis 24 hours later. We then hand-filtered extracted samples through Whatman GF/F (pore size 1.2 Âµm) filters before spectrophotometric analysis and corrected final values for phaeopigment.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Either alpine-above treeline or subalpine- below treeline
Either early summer- Visit_1 or late summer- Visit_2

codeDefinition.definition: The first visit accessed immediately after ice-off of the upper most lake in the drainage when hydrologic connectivity is high
The second visit accessed approximately 5 weeks later when hydrologic connectivity is low

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of the watershed where each lake is located

codeDefinition.definition: The Snowbank watershed consists of the following four lakes- Snowbank Lake Lion Lake II Lion Lake I and Thunder Lake
The Pear watershed consists of the following four lakes- Cony Lake Upper Hutcheson Lake Pear Reservoir Finch Lake
The Glacier Gorge watershed consists of the following four lakes- Frozen Lake Blue Lake Black Lake and Mills Lake
The Snowy watershed consists of the following four lakes- East Glacier Lake West Glacier Lake Little Brooklyn Lake and Jeep Lake
